sn35.153:4.1: “Mendicants, is there a method—apart from faith, personal preference, oral tradition, reasoned contemplation, or acceptance of a view after consideration—that a mendicant can rely on to declare their enlightenment? That is:
sn35.153:4.2: ‘I understand: “Rebirth is ended, the spiritual life has been lived, what had to be done has been done, there is no return to any state of existence.”’”
sn35.153:4.3: “Our teachings are rooted in the Buddha. He is our guide and refuge.
sn35.153:4.4: Sir, may the Buddha himself please clarify the meaning of this.
sn35.153:4.5: The mendicants will listen and remember it.”
sn35.153:4.6: “Well then, mendicants, listen and pay close attention, I will speak.”
sn35.153:4.9: “There is a method—apart from faith, personal preference, oral tradition, reasoned contemplation, or acceptance of a view after consideration—that a mendicant can rely on to declare their enlightenment. That is:
sn35.153:4.10: ‘I understand: “Rebirth is ended, the spiritual life has been lived, what had to be done has been done, there is no return to any state of existence.”’
sn35.153:5.4: Take a mendicant who sees a sight with the eye. When they have greed, hate, and delusion in them, they understand ‘I have greed, hate, and delusion in me.’
sn35.153:5.5: When they don’t have greed, hate, and delusion in them, they understand ‘I don’t have greed, hate, and delusion in me.’
sn35.153:5.8: are these things understood by faith, personal preference, oral tradition, reasoned contemplation, or acceptance of a view after consideration?”
sn35.153:5.10: “Aren’t they understood by seeing them with wisdom?”
sn35.153:5.12: “This is a method—apart from faith, personal preference, oral tradition, reasoned contemplation, or acceptance of a view after consideration—that a mendicant can rely on to declare their enlightenment. That is:
sn35.153:5.13: ‘I understand: “Rebirth is ended, the spiritual life has been lived, what had to be done has been done, there is no return to any state of existence.”’
sn35.153:6.1: Furthermore, when a mendicant hears a sound … smells an odor … tastes a flavor … feels a touch …
sn35.153:7.1: cognizes a phenomenon with the mind. When they have greed, hate, and delusion in them, they understand ‘I have greed, hate, and delusion in me.’
sn35.153:7.2: When they don’t have greed, hate, and delusion in them, they understand ‘I don’t have greed, hate, and delusion in me.’
sn35.153:7.5: are these things understood by faith, personal preference, oral tradition, reasoned contemplation, or acceptance of a view after consideration?”
sn35.153:7.7: “Aren’t they understood by seeing them with wisdom?”
sn35.153:7.9: “This too is a method—apart from faith, personal preference, oral tradition, reasoned contemplation, or acceptance of a view after consideration—that a mendicant can rely on to declare their enlightenment. That is:
sn35.153:7.10: ‘I understand: “Rebirth is ended, the spiritual life has been lived, what had to be done has been done, there is no return to any state of existence.”’”
